channel.description: A new prescription drug suggestion gained steam Thurs ., picking up support from key Republicans who have made a decision that President Bush's insurance policy for providing prescription drugs to seniors will be able to die a quiet loss of life, reports CBS Information Chief Washington Surgeon Bob Schieffer.Instead, they will push a bipartisan plan that follows the actual approach taken through the campaign by Al Gore  a plan that makes prescription medications available as a benefit for the Medicare right program.The strategy is part of a broad renovate of Medicare financed by two senators, Democrat John Breaux of Louisiana as well as Republican Bill Frist of Tennessee, who believe there's a growing consensus to generate prescription drugs part of Treatment. "Prescription drugs should be a part of Medicare. I don't consider there's a difference amid any group or organization that can feel that it should not,In . Breaux said.The Congressional Budget Office estimates your Breaux-Frist plan for all elderly people would cost $163 thousand over 10 years.A cornerstone of Gore's campaign was making prescription medication coverage a part of Treatment, but Mr. Bush has opposed which approach as too expensive. Mr. Bush back a limited plan that could provide coverage simply to the poorest seniors. He wants to give states a $12 billion dollars a year lump payment that they could distribute to seniors who needed help getting drugs.But now, Republican Sen. Charles Grassley involving Iowa, the new chairman of the Senate Finance Committee who will have fun playing the key role in shaping Medicare change, said Thursday they favors the Breaux-Frist way of make drugs an integral part of Medicare, a see other key Republicans are coming to share.Crucial Republican support makes the odds better than ever that medication legislation will be approved this year. So, within a presidential campaign that had a lot of ironies, add one more.(D)MMI Viacom Internet Services Inc. All Rights Set-aside. Two people in Congress are suggesting to outlaw the use of hand-held mobile devices while driving.Sen. Jon Corzine, D-N.T., Rep. Gary Ackerman, D-N.Y simply., introduced bills in the Senate and Property, respectively, that attempt to prevent accidents caused by distracted drivers.Corzine's bill would let states decide whether to allow drivers to use mobile phones with hands-free features. Under Ackerman's bill, drivers might use cell phones only with functions like an ear item or a speaker telephone.Both bills would allow states to demand penalties, such as charges or points with a driver's license. The legal guidelines is modeled after measures pending inside 40 states, such as New York and Nj.Also Tuesday, any government study identified no conclusive proof of cancer problems in connection with cell phone use. However the Government Accounting Place of work (GAO), which authored the report, also claimed it couldn't rule out the opportunity of future health risks.Sen. Joseph Lieberman, D-Conn., and Rep. Male impotence Markey, D-Mass., announced the findings at a news conference on Capitol Hill. The two urged the government to take a more active role in research on the possible health risks involving cell phone use.You will find 116 million cell phones used in the United States. We still are after the hurricane,In . Reynold J. Jennings, the company's main operating officer, mentioned from New Orleans.Tenet had been the largest private clinic company in the region. However its Memorial Medical Center as well as Lindy Boggs Medical Center remain shut down indefinitely, while a few suburban New Orleans medical centers, NorthShore Regional Medical Center in Slidell, Kenner Regional Medical Center as well as Meadowcrest Hospital in Gretna, are gradually returning to services.Tenet plans to reopen a number of medical offices from Memorial and two from Lindy Boggs in three to four weeks, which will let doctors resume their practices, and to reopen a new cardiac surgery initiate at Memorial within six months.Jennings said the prospects of reopening 347-bed Memorial "don't look good" because flooding in the lower two floors caused considerable damage. He said 188-bed Lindy Boggs endured less structural injury and reopening it could depend upon insurance settlements.The company also plans to website link its three suv hospitals with the New Orleans hospitals to create a wellbeing network known as NOLA Regional Health Network.The actual announcement sent Tenet stock falling. The shares dropped 53 pence or 5.8 percent, to $8.59 in afternoon investing on the New York Stock Exchange.
